    • Fitting distance metric algorithms

Fitting distance metric algorithms

Juan Luis Suárez Díaz

Source: vignettes/examples/fitting_dmls.Rmd
fitting_dmls.Rmd

First, we load the needed libraries.

library(datasets)
library(rDML)

We will use the iris dataset.

# Loading dataset
data(iris)
X = iris[1:4]
y = iris[5][,1]

We construct the NCA transformer, and we fit it with the data in iris.

# DML construction
nca = NCA()

# Fitting algorithm
nca$fit(X,y)

Once fitted, we can look at the algorithm metadata.

# We can look at the algorithm metadata after fitting it
meta = nca$metadata()
meta
## $num_iters
## [1] 2
## 
## $initial_expectance
## [1] 0.8380717
## 
## $final_expectance
## [1] 0.9549347

Also we can see the metric or the transformed we have learned.

# We can see the metric the algorithm has learned
M = nca$metric()
M
##            [,1]       [,2]      [,3]      [,4]
## [1,]  1.1895714  0.4409538 -1.894276 -1.672692
## [2,]  0.4409538  1.5526059 -1.821239 -1.692990
## [3,] -1.8942764 -1.8212391  5.656832  4.732213
## [4,] -1.6726925 -1.6929897  4.732213  5.519085
#Equivalent, we can see the learned linear map
L = nca$transformer()
L
##             [,1]        [,2]       [,3]       [,4]
## [1,]  0.85483243 -0.00198076 -0.3903096 -0.2908216
## [2,]  0.01822909  1.07767664 -0.3696151 -0.3295847
## [3,] -0.56577195 -0.50491497  2.0925983  1.2171912
## [4,] -0.37202515 -0.36915568  0.9944381  1.9606956

We can use the transformer to map data to the space defined by the learned distance.

# Finally, we can obtain the transformed data ...
Lx = nca$transform()
Lx[1:5,]
##          [,1]     [,2]       [,3]       [,4]
## [1,] 3.748115 3.281459 -1.4795635 -1.4050207
## [2,] 3.578139 2.738974 -1.1139516 -1.1460378
## [3,] 3.445807 2.987825 -1.3110401 -1.2449077
## [4,] 3.282460 2.804312 -0.7854517 -0.9719021
## [5,] 3.662434 3.387403 -1.4734778 -1.4047338
# ... or transform new data.
X_ = matrix(nrow = 3, ncol = 4, data = c(1,0,0,0,
                                         1,1,0,0,
                                         1,1,1,0))
Lx_ = nca$transform(X_)
Lx_
##            [,1]       [,2]      [,3]      [,4]
## [1,]  0.5640108 -0.3113556 0.6514192 1.5886705
## [2,] -0.2928024  0.7480919 0.7122762 1.5915399
## [3,] -0.3922904  0.7080616 1.5876833 0.6252824
